data.title: Screenwriters to Watch 2023
data.text:
Zack Ford

Writer, Producer for WATCHER

Biography

Zack Ford is a writer/producer who splits his time between LA, NY, and Key West. He is managed by Ben Pitts at Citizen Skull. He’s a NYU alum.

How did you get your start in screenwriting?

When I was 12 my mom wrote a screenplay for her MFA thesis at Binghamton University. It was how I learned what a screenplay was, and I started writing them immediately. When I was 16, I placed in the top 20% of the Nicholl, and I never looked back. I used macros on Word to format that script, because I didn’t have Final Draft software yet.

Detail some of the biggest lessons you have learned.

Hollywood is full of psychopaths who will try to stab you in the back even when it isn’t in their own best interest to do so. There is only one way to win: focus on your craft and keep producing new material.

What’s the hardest scene or project you’ve ever had to write in your career? How did you navigate the challenge?

I had writer’s block once in June 2004. If it happens to you, walk away from your computer and ignore your story until it demands for you to come back. Don’t come back until it tells you how to write it. If a good story thinks you’re turning your back on it, it will sing like a bird when you’re in the middle of doing something else. If it doesn’t, put it in a drawer and forget about it. Your story isn’t your baby. Play hardball: you crack it, it doesn’t crack you.

What was a major turning point in your career?

One time in the rainforest I witnessed an extraterrestrial column of energy rising from the center of the earth into the sky. I saw to my surprise that its roiling lava-like substance was made of story, and I realized the pen is mightier than the sword, and that everything we do, even using our own names, is based on some story we’re telling ourselves, because we too are made of story, and humanity is one big story. It made me excited to be a writer. Ironically, when I finally took my phone out of the Zip-Lock bag two weeks later, I had a voicemail telling me I’d optioned WATCHER.

What are some of your favorite films?

Amadeus, hands down. And, the original Nightmare on Elm Street, which I saw a special screening of at AFF in the late 90’s, hosted by Wes Craven himself.

Who are some of your favorite screenwriters? Who do you look to for inspiration?

Me. Your favorite screenwriter has to be you. Otherwise, your writing won’t improve because you’ll be constantly hung up on comparison and you’ll never tell the stories only you can tell. Are you making sure Quentin Tarantino is drinking enough water and doing his yoga and getting to bed early so he can get up and do his writing? No. You’re doing all of that for yourself, because you are your favorite screenwriter. It’s you.

Share a memorable experience sparked from Austin Film Festival?

I’ve been coming to AFF on and off for 25 years, starting when I was a teenager. It’s become a family vacation. The panels and speakers are always friendly and brilliant, and I always leave AFF inspired. After every festival, I invariably find myself scribbling ideas for new screenplays on Driskill or Stephen F. Austin hotel stationery on the airplane’s fold-out tray on the way home. I’m always glad I came. And getting a photo with Wes Craven at that aforementioned AFF screening was a defining moment in my childhood.

How have you been spending your time since being a part of Austin Film Festival?

Writing.

How has being part of the Austin Film Festival Community helped spark your storytelling journey or career?

Somehow, though I’m an introvert with a low social battery, I always leave AFF with about a dozen new friends. This is the festival where you will meet the right people, and you always learn something new at AFF. Panelists and attendees come to 10am panels with Texas-sized hangovers because they don’t want to miss a minute.

What are you looking forward to in 2023?

I’m looking forward to AFF’s 30th year. Don’t tell anyone, but I prefer AFF over SXSW. If you’re deciding between the two, SXSW has a State Fair sprawl, but AFF is intimate, streamlined, and built on camaraderie. Plus, AFF always has the best movie premieres

Any news with your project or career you would like to share?

I’m rewriting a film for Universal/Bazelevs. I’ve also got about a half-dozen other projects in various stages of development, and I’m working on a Part Three of my “How I Hijacked Hollywood” articles for Script Magazine.

Stevie Wain

@stayfunny_wain

Day Jobs

Writer of Day Jobs, Outcasts & New Hope

Bio

Stevie Wain grew up with Pennsylvania Jesus in a very small conservative town with one freshly out of the gay closet mom and one divorced bitter dad. Let’s just say… she can’t stop writing about it. She’s a legacy gay, filmmaker and writer whose latest produced tv pilot, Day Jobs, won the 2022 Audience Award at the 29th Austin Film Festival in which she starred, wrote and co-directed. She just participated in the 2022 Outfest Screenwriting Lab as a “Notable Writer” with her half hour script, Outcasts. Her other scripts have placed high in competitions like the 2021 ScreenCraft Screenwriting Fellowship, the 2021 Walt Disney Television Writing Program, the 2021 Austin Film Festival and more. She was a video producer for BuzzFeed, freelance writer for Bustle, creator of her own LA comedy show called, That’s So Gay! and has performed over 150 stand-up comedy shows in LA.

How did you get your start in screenwriting?

Honestly, premiering my TV pilot at AFF and winning the Audience Award has been great momentum. It gave me the notoriety that helped me get started with an entertainment lawyer and we’re in the middle of finding management. Of course, the real secret to that is the eight years of hard work I put into developing my craft as a writer and expanding my portfolio. When the door opens you can’t be empty handed, right?

Detail some of the biggest lessons you have learned.

Just to keep going. Have a great therapist. Learn a beginner’s mindset. Take classes. And more classes. Befriend other writers who understand how hard this journey can be and celebrate their victories like they’re your own. There’s really room for all of us, it just takes time and perseverance. And Brene Brown. I’ve watched Call to Courage like 30 times.

What’s the hardest scene or project you’ve ever had to write in your career? How did you navigate the challenge?

I just wrote a half hour dark comedy about queer middle school witches… and it’s a GIANT metaphor for my childhood and I think I’ve been trying to break this story…maybe my whole life. When things feel really personal and tough, I take my scripts through a writing class and get active feedback on the outline so I don’t lose myself in all of the possibilities. The real key is knowing “why” you want to write something and then funneling all of your story choices through that specific want. Like I wanted gay people to feel magic so I wrote a show where being gay LITERALLY MEANS you are magical.

What was a major turning point in your career?

I just accepted representation with an entertainment lawyer and we’re actively trying to put together a team and honestly, that’s been the most exciting start to the new year. I feel like I’m finally breaking in and I’m just so excited to work in a more professional setting.

What are some of your favorite films?

My favorite movie is Dan in Real Life and my favorite TV show of all time is Transparent. Both stories are about families who desperately want to be loved and struggle to see each other. They’re honest, down to earth, painfully funny and are the types of projects I want to be making.

Who are some of your favorite screenwriters? Who do you look to for inspiration?

I love this question! Hands down, Samantha Strauss and Joey Soloway. The End is Samantha Strauss’s TV show and me and my partner literally clapped at the TV when these two elderly women kiss… like the tension built towards that intimacy was phenomenal. Joey Soloway created Transparent and of course, it has my whole heart. The balance of queer flawed funny people just trying to do their best is my cup of tea.

Share a memorable experience sparked from Austin Film Festival?

Talking on the episodic storytelling panel at AFF was a great moment for everyone in my film category to bond. And it made me feel like… “Oh wow, this is what I’m supposed to be doing. Like, gushing about writing is where I belong.” It led to everyone on the panel feeling really close and supportive of each other’s films. And we continue to be supportive of each other’s creative journeys and that’s something I’m really grateful for.

How have you been spending your time since being a part of Austin Film Festival?

Hustle bustle baby! I just participated in the Outfest Screenwriting Lab as a “Notable Writer” with my gay witch script and it was a dream experience. I also just signed with an entertainment lawyer and using the momentum started from AFF has been the exact help I needed to get my foot in the door. Of course, working on my next project, finding a manager, taking a new writing class, doom scrolling on IG. The ushe.

How has being part of the Austin Film Festival Community helped spark your storytelling journey or career?

It’s given me a lot of confidence to feel proud of my work and the kinds of stories I’ve been telling. Sometimes you feel a little niche in your own world, writing about things you know and to experience the audiences at Austin relate and connect to my show about a nanny/comedian who falls in love with the mom she babysits for… It made me feel like I belonged. Like the flaws in me might be the same flaws in you and we’re all just trying to work on it. It honestly felt healing.

What are you looking forward to in 2023?

I’m excited to pitch my TV show and fill out my team of reps as I continue to develop new ideas for shows.

Any news with your project or career you would like to share?

My work was featured in Collider right after AFF and that was such an honor.

Nick Richey

@nickrichey8

1-800-Hot-Nite & The Banana King (Semi-Finalist)

Writer/Director for Low Low and 1-800-Hot-Nite

Bio

Nick Richey’s writer/director debut, Low Low, received critical acclaim from NPR, LA Times and Variety and is now streaming on Paramount+. His sophomore writing/directing effort, 1-800-HOT-NITE, had its world premiere at the Santa Barbara International Film Festival in 2022, won the audience award at Dances With Films, Best Director at Vashon Island Film Festival, nominated for the Grand Prix at Deauville Festival du Americain and was a marquee film selection at the Austin Film Festival. The Film was released domestically by Quiver Distribution in 2022 and internationally with Odin’s Eye Entertainment. Nick recently had a television series titled, Bedlam in development at CBS Studios and another series titled, The Montego Bay Sweepstakes in development at ABC Studios with co-creator, Tommy Dewey. He co-wrote Room 203, released theatrically in April 2022 by Voltage and Vertical Entertainment. He is now entering pre-production on his third feature film, BITS, BODY AND BONES.

How did you get your start in screenwriting?

I was an actor first. I was always a storyteller but acting was my ingress to filmmaking. The first film I acted in was written and directed by Jonathan Hensleigh and I was inspired listening to him talk about writing some of my favorite action films from my teen years. When the shoot ended, I raced home, bought some screenwriting books, sat down and spent 2 years writing my first screenplay. It was complete garbage. I threw it away. Then I wrote a second screenplay and it got optioned by a production company at Sony Studios. I’ve written every day since.

Detail some of the biggest lessons you have learned.

I’ve learned that there’s no such thing as not enough time to write. When I was waiting tables and had three minutes, I would pull out my server notepad and instead of jotting down omelette ingredients, I was writing dialogue, outlining ideas and building characters. If I write a half page or ten pages it’s a successful day. The second part to this is the fact that you absolutely have to sit down and put the story on the page regardless of your inspiration level that day. Push through!

What’s the hardest scene or project you’ve ever had to write in your career? How did you navigate the challenge?

The hardest scene I’ve had to write was a scene from my latest film 1-800-HOT-NITE. Spoiler: There’s a moment when the phone sex operator tackles the main character to the ground and waxes poetic about life. Some things don’t have to be subtext. Some things are said aloud, screaming, crying. We talk like that too. Not every person spouts the ingredients for banana pancakes as an allegory for losing your innocence. Sometimes I’m scared to let those direct words fly and lean in. Luckily, I had the best actors and they made it all feel real.

What was a major turning point in your career?

A major turning point in my career occurred when I got my first network series pitch. I was brutally unprepared and had zero experience pitching a show. I realized at that moment that I’m in a room, essentially asking a company to invest millions of dollars in a kernel of an idea. It’s like pitching tech in Silicon Valley. Since then, I’ve always gone above and beyond expectations, whether that’s self-financing a film or shooting a trailer for a series idea. I’ve met so many amazing people in the festival circuit because of that drive and have had two shows picked up for development at CBS Studios and ABC Studios (neither show made it but I’m proud of those projects).

What are some of your favorite films?

I am obsessed with The Lord of The Rings trilogy. I watch those movies on repeat. I think Moonlight, In Bruges, Dr. Strangelove, Once Upon A Time In Hollywood, Children of Men and Jaws are masterpieces. I love a lot of movies.

Who are some of your favorite screenwriters? Who do you look to for inspiration?

I love the Gilroys and Scott Frank, Martin Mcdonaugh, and Quentin Tarantino. Christopher Nolan has the most spectacular imagination. Issa Rae is a major inspiration for me in television.

Share a memorable experience sparked from Austin Film Festival?

I honestly have so many memorable experiences from AFF. The camaraderie was unrivaled in our entire festival experience. There was a particular spark that I loved though. I had recently parted ways with my lit management. Despite having a successful indie film, I just didn’t feel like we connected anymore. I had a screenplay make it as a semi-finalist at Austin and I hadn’t had a chance to do anything with the script before the festival. While in Austin, a producer read the logline and reached out and now we’re collaborating on a series pitch. Additionally, Joey Tuccio from Roadmap Writers reached out via Twitter and ended up sending the script to a couple of amazing production companies. These are moments and connections that wouldn’t have happened without AFF.

How have you been spending your time since being a part of Austin Film Festival?

Since AFF we released our feature film, 1-800-Hot-Nite to the public and have sold the film in some amazing foreign territories. I love getting to see people connecting with the film from Brazil to Montana. I’ve also begun casting and putting things in motion for pre-production on my next directorial effort. I recently decided to enroll in a tv writing certificate program at Writing Pad. I want to keep improving and challenging myself to become a better writer. I also plan to do the same with Roadmap Writers.

How has being part of the Austin Film Festival Community helped spark your storytelling journey or career?

Being part of the Austin Film Festival really reignited my passion to continue to learn about writing. I would sit in the panels and listen to other amazing writers tell their tales of failures and success and it made me feel like I was part of this larger community. Not only have I kept in contact with other writers and filmmakers that were selected in competition, but I’ve also felt extremely supported by the programming team and the festival founder, Barbara. This was my first time at AFF and I plan to attend every year, whether I have a film or screenplay in competition or not.

What are you looking forward to in 2023?

I’m really looking forward to getting back behind the camera in 2023. I plan to shoot BITS, BODY and BONES! I’m also really excited to take a couple new television shows to market. I haven’t had a show picked up to series yet and I’m really going to fight to make this the year. Most importantly, both my mother and mother-in-law were diagnosed with cancer in 2022 and I’m excited for both of them to finish treatment and be cancer free in 2023!

Any news with your project or career you would like to share?

I was really honored to be nominated for Breakout Writer/Director of the year by the Indiana Film Journalists. My lead actor in 1-800-HOT-NITE, Dallas Dupree Young, was also nominated as Breakout Actor. We’re making offers to our lead actors for Bits, Body and Bones so hopefully there will be some announcements on that end soon.

The Pierce Brothers – Brett Pierce + Drew Pierce

@piercebrett @drewdraws

The Wretched

Writer/Director The Wretched & DeadHeads

Bio

The Pierce Brothers’ horror film THE WRETCHED opened in drive-in theaters on May 1st, 2020, by IFC Midnight and was the #1 movie in the US for six consecutive weekends, making it the first film to hold that record since the release of AVATAR in 2009.

How did you get your start in screenwriting?

We had written our first two independent features and coming off the success of the second one, The Wretched in 2020, we were able to land our first studio writing assignments.

Detail some of the biggest lessons you have learned.

Just write for yourself and trust your own instincts. Fitting into boxes for other people doesn’t do you any favors and ultimately anything we write we have to be passionate about. That being said, after we write the passionate story, we love dearly we then tell people to be brutal with their criticism. The feedback has always made our scripts better no matter how hard it is to hear.

What’s the hardest scene or project you’ve ever had to write in your career? How did you navigate the challenge?

We had written a reboot of a horror franchise last year and it was very difficult to get the first act into shape because it required redefining the concept while making sure the fans of the previous iteration recognized the DNA of the original they fell in love with. We dealt with it by just putting in the time and grinding it out. Ultimately, we loved how it turned out and that was the result of just putting in the hours and getting a lot of feedback.

What was a major turning point in your career?

When The Wretched was released to huge success at drive-ins during the pandemic. We were number one at the box office for six weeks and everyone in Hollywood had to read about it in the trades. It got us in the room with everyone in town to talk about the next horror project we wanted to make.

What are some of your favorite films?

Halloween (1978), Jaws, Signs, Poltergeist, Fright Night, Evil Dead 2, Empire of the Sun, Raiders of the Lost Ark

Who are some of your favorite screenwriters? Who do you look to for inspiration?

Vince Gilligan, Mike Flanagan, Jane Espenson, Lawrence Kasdan

Share a memorable experience sparked from Austin Film Festival?

Sitting in a tiny room with Lawrence Kasdan and a few others listening to him talk about writing Raiders of the Lost Ark and realizing the writing experience is just as difficult even for a film you perceive as perfect.

How have you been spending your time since being a part of Austin Film Festival?

Writing specs between writing assignments and working on film/tv pitches.

How has being part of the Austin Film Festival Community helped spark your storytelling journey or career?

AFF always reminds us that screenwriting isn’t as lonely as it feels when you’re fighting through writing something. There’s a ton of wonderful writers to learn from and be inspired by at AFF and that’s needed to keep hacking away at the laptop.

What are you looking forward to in 2023?

Making our new horror film this year. We’re getting to work with storytellers we greatly admire and we’re excited that the film is a new horror concept. We love a good horror franchise but it’s a modern miracle to get a horror film made that’s not a sequel or remake and we love the challenge of doing something new.

Any news with your project or career you would like to share? Include links so we can help spread the news.

Room 428 is the horror film we’re writing/directing for Screen Gems and it’s produced by Scott Derrikson (Black Phone, Dr. Strange) and C. Robert Cargill (Black Phone, Dr. Strange)

Grace (Ge) Gao

@stariagao

Old Maiden’s Prayer

Independent Writer/Director

Bio

Originally from China, Grace moved to OC, California, with her family at the age of 16, then escaped the suburbs to pursue her dream as a writer/director at NYU Tisch. Years of wandering on two suitcases and working for international co-productions in Australia and Asia, brought Grace home to writing. Her stories examine how Asian women survive places they don’t belong and blaze their own trails. In addition to the recognition at Austin Film Festival, Grace’s bilingual feature script OLD MAIDEN’S PRAYER is also a Humanitas New Voices Fellowship 2022 semi-finalist, and a Sundance Development Lab 2023 second-rounder. She will greet the world with a sci-fi action feature script and an Hour-Long historical drama pilot upon graduating from USC’s Writing for Screen and Television MFA in May 2023.

How did you get your start in screenwriting?

I started writing screenplays during my sophomore year at NYU Tisch. Although my concentration was directing, and I have made four festival-running short films during my undergraduate years, I managed to complete two feature screenplays at the same time. The very first accolade I received was for my psycho-thriller feature script NARCISSUS, which was a finalist at Screencraft Film Fund 2019. The proof-of-concept short film for NARCISSUS also became an official selection at LA Shorts International Film Festival 2021.

Detail some of the biggest lessons you have learned.

Don’t sprint a marathon. A writer’s career goes on for a lifetime. Each small step I take matters, and each failure that occurs will help me grow. Living my personal life mindfully is the best way to cumulate inspirations. To thy own self be true.

What’s the hardest scene or project you’ve ever had to write in your career? How did you navigate the challenge?

I am currently revising my thesis feature script, a sci-fi action film that requires elaborate world-building and sharp social commentary on specific issues Asian American women face collectively. It is extra challenging because this is my first attempt to write this genre, and the story’s message forces me to reflect on my personal relationship with the world I live in profoundly, despite many levels of discomfort that I discovered along the way. Thankfully, I have a group of classmates who are very invested in what I want to say and two brilliant professors (Jack Epps Jr. and Don Bohlinger) guiding our rewrite process. I am diving back into the index cards and outlining before I tackle the pages again to iron out some skeletal and conceptual issues before creating extra scene works.

What was a major turning point in your career?

If I may, the “turning” moments in my career were not “points” but “lines”. I see the growth process as a writer closer to knitting a net than drawing an upward line. The importance of “plant” is also paramount in real life if we expect a certain “payoff”. If I have to name a moment when I felt tangible acceleration in my career, that would be becoming a Finalist at Austin Film Festival while living in Los Angeles permanently.

What are some of your favorite films?

Little Miss Sunshine; Black Swan; The Proposal; Kung Fu Hustle

Who are some of your favorite screenwriters? Who do you look to for inspiration?

Diablo Cody; Florian Zeller; The Daniels; Lisa Joy

Share a memorable experience sparked from Austin Film Festival?

Meg LeFauve’s masterclass was a full house, and everyone was taking notes attentively like it was our first day learning about screenwriting.

How have you been spending your time since being a part of Austin Film Festival?

I have followed up on most of the connections I made at the festival with Zoom calls or coffee dates and continued to develop new works.

How has being part of the Austin Film Festival Community helped spark your storytelling journey or career?

It was my first time attending Austin Film Festival in October 2022, and I met many finalists who kept coming back to the festival every year. They shared so much wisdom on navigating the festival and beyond with me, and I was genuinely moved by how much they believe in the festival’s community. The accolade from Austin helped me stand out as an early-career writer when I met executives and producers who were just getting to know me. It is an affirmation of my craft as a writer and allows me to focus on presenting my authentic self as a human being.

What are you looking forward to in 2023?

Completing my current two passion projects and being open to more creatives who will cross path with me on my journey.

Any news with your project or career you would like to share? Include links so we can help spread the news.

Old Maiden’s Prayer is now in development for financing and production as my directorial debut.

Saeed Crumpler

@balance510

Staff Writer for Flatbush Misdemeanors

Biography

Saeed Crumpler most recently signed a development deal with SONY TV, he’s been staffed on FLATBUSH MISDEMEANORS for Showtime. He consulted on BLINDSPOTTING for Lionsgate, working closely with Rafael Casal and Daveed Diggs. Also in 2021, Saeed completed a feature rewrite on MTV’s HIP-HOP FAMILY CHRISTMAS for Jamie Foxx and Datari Turner, as well as a biopic about legendary underground hip-hop artist Mac Dre for Double Down Pictures. A Bay Area BIPOC screenwriter with a music background, Saeed is a graduate of the UCLA Professional Program in Writing for Television. As a former hip hop artist who came up in the hyphy scene, Saeed has recorded with the likes of Kendrick Lamar and Chamillionaire. He strives to bridge the gap to bring stories from the subculture into the mainstream. Saeed was a fellow in the 2021 Nickelodeon Writing Program.

How did you get your start in screenwriting?

I got my first break after being in the Nickelodeon fellowship in 2020. Nickelodeon and Showtime are both in the Paramount Plus family, later in the program, Nickelodeon passed my script FLIP to the TV show Flatbush Misdemeanors. That’s how I got staffed on my first tv show.

Detail some of the biggest lessons you have learned.

The biggest lesson I learned is writing is rewriting and fail early and often. If you’re an upcoming writer and are currently failing – you are very close to success. Just keep going. The writers who don’t make it are the ones who quit.

What’s the hardest scene or project you’ve ever had to write in your career? How did you navigate the challenge?

One thing I learned is that every project is hard and has its own little problems. I look at each script as a puzzle that needs to be figured out. You can’t attack one script’s problems the same way you attack another.

What was a major turning point in your career?

The major turning point in my career was my “not giving a f*uck”. Once I stopped caring about the results and feedback and just consistently put myself out there without being worried about the outcome – things started happening for me.

What are some of your favorite films?

This is a tough question. But I will give 3 films: 1) Pulp Fiction 2) Do The Right Thing 3) Seven

Who are some of your favorite screenwriters? Who do you look to for inspiration?

Screenwriters I look up to Quentin Tarantino and Aaron Sorkin. Writers I look up to: Stephen King, Octavia Butler and August Wilson

Share a memorable experience sparked from Austin Film Festival?

A memorable experience from AFF was getting off a panel I was speaking on and talking to a line of screenwriters all sharing their experiences.

How have you been spending your time since being a part of Austin Film Festival?

I came back from AFF, energized and ready to write – so daily I’ve been working on several projects.

What are you looking forward to in 2023?

I’m looking forward to meeting more talented writers, producers, and executives in 2023. My goal is to sell a couple of feature scripts and a couple of tv shows.

Any news with your project or career you would like to share? Include links so we can help spread the news.

Saeed Crumpler Overall Deal Sony Pictures Television

Ana Maria Defillo

@adefillo

Momentous

Producer for Desus & Mero

Bio

Ana is a Caracas-born, Miami-raised, Dominican writer. Before her career in TV, she paved her road to hell as a Christian missionary, human rights grad student, & nonprofit professional. Now she spreads her gospel of cynicism as a comedy writer. She’s an alum of NHMC’s Scriptwriters Program. Her dark satirical comedy, Momentous, won at the 2022 Austin Film Festival.

How did you get your start in screenwriting?

My first big break in my screenwriting career was probably getting into the NHMC Screenwriters Fellowship. I met so many great writers turned friends. It gave me the connections and confidence to keep growing as a writer and artist.

Detail some of the biggest lessons you have learned.

The advice/lesson that changed everything for me came from a fellow NHMC alum and brilliant development exec, Erika Kennair. Paraphrasing here but essentially when people read my script they should be able to say, “Oh, this is definitely an Ana script.” Which is basically another way to say, “Find your voice.” Finding my voice always felt elusive and frustrating but for some reason her words flipped a switch. After reflecting on who I was, why I want to be a writer, and what I want to say as an artist, it yelled, “I’m down here, bitch!” It was in me this whole time but I let it turn into a whisper. When I said fuck it, this is me, it’s okay if not everyone digs it (shout out to my therapists over the years!), it changed everything. I finally became confident about my work (the most important thing), won AFF, and got repped by one of my dream companies all in the same year. Turns out all the clichés we’re told about “making it” are clichés for a good reason. And if you can, get a good therapist! Working through your shit makes your writing stand out from the crowd.

What’s the hardest scene or project you’ve ever had to write in your career? How did you navigate the challenge?

Ironically, but not surprisingly, the hardest project I’ve had to write was Momentous, the script that won at AFF, got me repped, and best exemplifies my voice. It was my first attempt writing a pilot so of course it had to be a high-concept satirical comedic mystery. I don’t know what I was thinking. Simplicity bores me and I like a challenge? And I’ve always been ambitious to a point of delusion, I guess. There was no magic formula. I just kept at it. It was brutal. It went through SO MANY versions and revisions over the years. Several of those versions probably made people question my abilities as a writer. Not their fault I guess since I was starting at 100 instead of 1. I took breaks and wrote “simpler” scripts but always came back. I knew it would be special and I loved it too much. Once I cracked it I experienced another cliché I thought was bullshit, it POURED out of me. It felt so easy. I’d never been happier. Of course it went through many edits after, but I figured out how to accomplish the million and one things I wanted to do with the story while still being funny. That’s all that mattered.

What was a major turning point in your career?

Winning at AFF was definitely a major turning point. It helped legitimize me as a Real Writer to the industry and find the perfect manager. (With the help of Roadmap Writers!)

What are some of your favorite films?

Purple Rain will never not make me smile. An absolute cinematic masterpiece. Don’t ask me how many times I’ve seen it or why.

Who are some of your favorite screenwriters? Who do you look to for inspiration?

There are several, but the biggest one right now is Nathan Fielder. It’s funny, most of the writers I adore are also performers, I am not. But Nathan Fielder is on a level that I dream to attain. I also think our brains function similarly in the sense of how we process the world, but I’m not a white cis man so I had to assimilate in a way he didn’t. Watching him embrace whatever the fuck is “wrong” with brains like ours has been empowering and motivating. I really respect artists who continue to push themselves to evolve and grow not only as artists, but as people. It’s so easy to phone it in after a big success. Sadly, many comedians I admire have. But that’s not why I’m here so it’s great to see you can evolve and continue to pay the bills as a comedy writer.

Share a memorable experience sparked from Austin Film Festival?
